'Twentieth Century Innovations'
Brings Violinist Dawes to JHU
Internationally famed violinist
Andrew Dawes will be the featured soloist March 4th, when
the "Twentieth Century Innovations" series will return for its
second presentation at Johns
Hopkins following a successful
concert earlier this year.
A native of Alberta, Canada,
Andrew Dawes has been studying
the violin since the age of eight.
He has toured Canada with orchestras and as a soloist and has
won international recognition as
a prize winner in the 1962
Jeunesses Musicales of Canada.
An honors graduate of the
Geneva Conservatoire in addition, Mr. Dawes returned to
Geneva in 1964 to receive the
"Concours de Virtuosite."
Appearing with Mr. Dawes as
an assisting artist will be Claude
Bayard, a native of Montreal and
one of Canada's most outstanding young pianists.

the second of Mr. Gunther

An expanding research program
to improve ship and submarine
performance and reliability
The U. S. Navy Marine Engineering Laboratory
conducts RDT&E in naval shipboard and submarine machinery & auxiliary systems (electrical, nuclear, mechanical propulsion, control,
instrumentation, etc.). In addition to recommending basic improvements in performance
and reliability, the Laboratory concentrates on
ship silencing ideas, new concepts in energy
conversion and control, better ways to minimize friction and wear, special operating machinery for deep-diving vessels of all kinds,
and tough, resistant naval alloys able to meet
all ocean environmental requirements.

find this an excellent place to gain perspective,
insight, and professional recognition .. . on
projects of national importance.

The Laboratory buildings—now more than 50
of them—house some of the finest research,
experimental, and evaluation equipments of
their kind ... such as highspeed computers,
electric power generators, vibration and shock
test stands, metals composition analysis instruments, cryogenic storage and handling facilities, physics & chemistry labs ... and complex
instruments for measuring strain, stress, pressure, acceleration, velocity, performance, and
reliability. The Laboratory grounds are right
on the Severn River, just off the Chesapeake
Bay, and resemble a modern industrial park.

all its old-time charm, while offering quick
access to Washington, Baltimore, and ocean
resorts, and such universities as Maryland,

Beating The Rap
Even with all this excitement,
there is probably no one on
campus who will be sad to see
the season of rush pass. The
freshmen, dormitory residents in
particular, will undoubtedly regret the absence of that sudden
rap on the door, the smiling face
and extended hand. But they can
always find consolation in their
academic pursuits.
Nevertheless, those students
who have survived the trial of
the bottomless beer glass and
passed the test of the mysterious
black ball and decided to join a
social fraternity have embarked
upon a path which will certainly
round out their college life. Although at times they wondered
whether they were rushing or
being
rushed, whether they
should rush to Or away, their
own reason and the good counsel
of a multitude of upperclassmen
has prevailed.

'Ford Motor

'Stuff 'Cakes!
Win Contest
Five starved, drooling HoPPies
Will join five equally hungry
Goucher girls to dive into piles
of free pancakes Tuesday, March
2, at 4 P.M. at the House of
Pancakes Restaurant, 5201 York
Road, as part of the fifth annual
Intercollegiate House of Pancakes Eating Contest.
The five boys, who will be
chosen on a first como-first
served basis, will be paired off
With Goucher girls for thirty
minutes of stuffing. Students
can enter at the Public Relations Office in Homewood House.
The team consuming the most
"silver dollar" sized cakes (the
Use of syrup is optional) will be
eligible for regional prizes of
records, trophies, school blazers,
and the national first-prize, an
RCA color television.
The contest, which began in
California in 1960, has spread
nationwide and now includes
eighty-seven restaurants in sixteen states. Pancake totals of
the best eaters in the Baltimore
contest will be compared wih
those of hundreds of other collegians across the country to
determine the winners. Other
Universities competing include
Southern California, UCLA,
Miami of Florida, Harvard, Radcliffe, and Yale.
Judges for the contest will be
Baltimorean civic and business
leaders as well as representatives
of both Hopkins and Gaudier.
The restaurant authorities invite
all students blessed with strong
stomach to attend also.
Shrove Tuesday, the day before
Lent, is a natural pick for the
Contest. It has been traditicnaly
set aside or the consumption of
hordes of pancakes.
Last year's grand prize winners
Were awarded all-expense paid
trips to London, England.

The Big Change
In the annual report of the President, printed in
the February issue of the Johns Hopkins Magazine, Dr.
Eisenhower shows himself to he a man keenly aware
of the manifold and complex objectives, methods, and
problems of Hopkins.
In his report, devoted almost exclusively to a
discussion of the Long Range Planning Committee,
Dr. Eisenhower enumerates many of the topics under
discussion by the committee. Obviously he and many
faculty and administrative personnel are aware of the
need for discussion and planning that must precede
even the most necessary action.
But the Long Range Planning Committee can no
longer be considered something "for members only,"
something that only the members know about. Combined with ['dews-Letter accounts of the undergraduate
and graduate subcommittees of the LRPC, the President's report provides any interested person with a
meaty introduction to the committee's purposes, methods, and deliberations.

FOOD FOR PEACE
The Hopkins Community is
doubtless unaware that a fresh
approach to international countel-force diplomacy was created
here last week. Credit for the
breakthrough goes to The Johns
Hopkins Chapter of The Young
Americans For Freedom who
have thankfully offered an alternative to street riot, summit
conference, coup, guerilla insurgence and nuclear blackmail. In
their "Feast for Vietnam" the
Y.A.F. has successfully demonstrated that we can win the cold
war if only we are willing to eat
our way out of it.
It would be a mistake to stop
now and rest on the well
deserved laurels of the Vietnam

feast. Robert McNamara, steelrimmed-trustworthy, and president of Ford Motor Company at
the time of the Edsel) has made
it clear that if we do not fight in
Vietnam we will have to do so
elsewhere. Thus I propose teams
of students lining the walls of
Levering: Nibbling for Nigeria,
Munching for Munich, Chomping for Chad, Slurping for Senegal, Chewing for Chile, Swallowing for Swaziland, Burping for
Burma, Belching for Berlin and
Lunching for Lyndon.
Let the American fudgecicle
replace the communist ink bottle as the favored weapon of
embassy stormers. What better
way could be found to show that

negotiated peace eats it on a
stick. "We want to fight the cold
war with America's surplus and
bounty," the Y.AIF. spokesman
told me. Let us then go and
gather the countless junked
shells of automobiles that litter
our countryside, gather them up
and fly them to Asia. Dropping
them on the fringes of South
Vietnam would effectively cut
communist supply lines and seal
the border for eternity. The action would handily eliminate the
need for costly air raids.
It is tragic that young men are
dying in Vietnam when they
could be at the university
munching
potato chips and
salted pretzels.

Way To Express Concern
Jennifer Leighton, one of the
Goucher fasters, said that their
fast was a continuance of the
movement started at George
Washington University. "It is an
extreme way to express our concern so people will take us seriously," she noted.
The girls put prepared statements in all the mail boxes and
maintained a literature table in
the post office for a few hours a
day. They also spent much time
talking to girls in the dorms.

Hop SDS Members
Demonstrate Despite
YAF Protestations
Last Saturday morning, members of the Johns Hopkins SDS
/net at Levering Hall to make
final preparations for their Protest at the White House over
our government's policy in Viet
Nam.
They were met there by a
group of four students who had
come to Levering to convince
them of "the error of your
ways." "We are not, here to stop
You from making your trip. We
only want to reason with you."
However, as the cars carrying the
demonstrators tried to leave
campus, a road block was set up
by these "Young Americans for
Pmedom." A new Oldsmobile

Because he joined Western Electric
Jim Brown, Northwestern University, '62, came
with Western Electric because he had heard about
the Company's concern for the continued development of its engineers after college graduation.
Jim has his degree in industrial engineering and
is continuing to learn and grow in professional
stature through Western Electric's Graduate Engineering Training Program. The objectives and educational philosophy of this Program are in the best
of academic traditions, designed for both experienced and new engineers.
Like other Western Electric engineers, Jim
started out in this Program with a six-week course
to help in the transition from the classroom to
industry. Since then, Jim Brown has continued to
take courses that will help him keep up with the
newest engineering techniques in communications.

This training, together with formal college
engineering studies, has given Jim the ability to
develop his talents to the fullest extent. His present
responsibilities include the solution of engineering problems in the manufacture of moly-permalloy core rings, a component used to improve the
quality of voice transmission.
If you set the highest standards for yourself,
enjoy a challenge, and have the qualifications
we're looking for — we want to talk to you! Opportunities exist now for electrical, mechanical and
industrial engineers, and for physical science, liberal arts and business majors. For more information, get your copy of the Western Electric Career

1. F. Stone, noted political commentator, and editor, addressed
the assembled demonstrators. He
stressed the catastrophic effects
of any nuclear war, and gave a
detailed history of Vietnam from
World War II to the present. He
stressed our failure to live up to
the Atlantic Charter when we
did not persuade the French to
get out of Indo China as we had
led these people to believe.
He also mentioned the American violation of the Geneva
agreement by its refusal to allow
free elections and by our arms
buildup. He described Ho Chi
Minh as a Nationalist leader who
was forced into the aims of the
Communists by American opposition. Stone praised the Johnson
Administration's policies in Eastern Europe and suggested that
they also be applied to the situation in the Far East. He concluded that the Vietnamese War
was not primarily an invasion
from the North but, rather, a
civil war. He finally stressed that
the North Vietnamese government was not installed as a puppet government but was elected
by an overwhelming majority of
the people.
After Stone spoke, the meeting
broke up and the students returned.

THE BEARD OF AVON
Topic for today is that perennial favorite of English majorsil
that ever-popular crowd pleaser, that good sport and great
American—William Shakespeare (or "The Swedish Nightin.
gale" as he is better known as).
First let us examine the persistent theory that Shakespeare (or
"The Pearl of the Pacific" as he is jocularly called) is not the
real author of his plays. Advocates of this theory insist the plays
are so full of classical allusions and learned references that. they
couldn't possibly have been written by the son of an illiterate
country butcher.
To which I reply "Faugh!" Was not the great Spinoza's fat her
a humble woodcutter? Was not the immortal Isaac N \\ 11111'S
father a simple second baseman?(The elder Newton,itici(lcittal-;
ly, is one of history's truly pathetic figures. He was, by all accounts, the greatest second baseman of his time, but baseball,!
alas, had not yet been invented. It used to break young Isaac's
heart to see his father get up every morning, put on uniform,
spikes, glove, and cap, and stand alertly behind second base,
bent forward, eyes narrowed, waiting, waiting, waiting. That's
all—waiting. Isaac loyally sat in the bleachers and yelled "Good
show, Dad!" and stuff like that, but everyone else in town sniggered derisively, made coarse gestures, and pelted the Newtons
with overripe fruit—figs for the elder Newton, apples for the
younger. Thus, as we all know, the famous moment came when
Isaac Newton,struck in the head with an apple, leapt to his feet,
shouted "Europa!" and announced the third law of motion:"For
every action there is an opposite and equal reaction!'

Shakespeare's most important play is, of course, Hamlet (or,

the story of Hamlet., Prince of Denmark, who one night sees a
ghost upon the battlements.(Possibly it is a goat he sees; I have

upset by seeing this ghost (or goat.) that he stabs Polonius and

the king, who hollers, "Get thee to a tannery!" Thereupon
Ophelia refuses her food until Laertes shouts, "Get thee to a
beanery!" Ophelia is so cross that she chases her little dog out of
the room,crying,"Out,damned Spot!" She is fined fifty shillings
for cussing, but Portia,in an eloquent plea, gets the sentence
muted to life imprisonment. Thereupon King Lear and Queen
Mab proclaim a festival—complete with kissing games and a
pie-eating contest. Everybody has a perfectly splendid time until
Banquo's ghost(or goat)shows up. This so unhinges Richard III
that he drowns his cousin, Butt Malmsey. This leads to a lively
discussion, during which everyone is killed. The little dog Spot

Our hero now has croaked,

Brings Violinist Dawes to JHU
Internationally famed violinist
Andrew Dawes will be the featured soloist March 4th, when
the "Twentieth Century Innovations" series will return for its
second presentation at Johns
Hopkins following a successful
concert earlier this year.
A native of Alberta, Canada,

the violin since the age of eight.
He has toured Canada with orchestras and as a soloist and has
won international recognition as
a prize winner in the 1962
Jeunesses Musicales of Canada.
An honors graduate of the
Geneva Conservatoire in addition, Mr. Dawes returned to
Geneva in 1964 to receive the
"Concours de Virtuosite."
Appearing with Mr. Dawes as
an assisting artist will be Claude
Bayard, a native of Montreal and
one of Canada's most outstanding young pianists.

An expanding research program
to improve ship and submarine
performance and reliability
The U. S. Navy Marine Engineering Laboratory
conducts RDT&E in naval shipboard and submarine machinery & auxiliary systems (electrical, nuclear, mechanical propulsion, control,
instrumentation, etc.). In addition to recommending basic improvements in performance
and reliability, the Laboratory concentrates on
ship silencing ideas, new concepts in energy
conversion and control, better ways to minimize friction and wear, special operating machinery for deep-diving vessels of all kinds,
and tough, resistant naval alloys able to meet
all ocean environmental requirements.

The Laboratory buildings—now more than 50
of them—house some of the finest research,
experimental, and evaluation equipments of
their kind ... such as highspeed computers,
electric power generators, vibration and shock
test stands, metals composition analysis instruments, cryogenic storage and handling facilities, physics & chemistry labs ... and complex
instruments for measuring strain, stress, pressure, acceleration, velocity, performance, and
reliability. The Laboratory grounds are right
on the Severn River, just off the Chesapeake
Bay, and resemble a modern industrial park.

Win Contest
Five starved, drooling HoPPies
Will join five equally hungry
Goucher girls to dive into piles
of free pancakes Tuesday, March
2, at 4 P.M. at the House of
Pancakes Restaurant, 5201 York
Road, as part of the fifth annual
Intercollegiate House of Pancakes Eating Contest.
The five boys, who will be
chosen on a first como-first
served basis, will be paired off
With Goucher girls for thirty
minutes of stuffing. Students
can enter at the Public Relations Office in Homewood House.
The team consuming the most
"silver dollar" sized cakes (the
Use of syrup is optional) will be
eligible for regional prizes of
records, trophies, school blazers,
and the national first-prize, an
RCA color television.
The contest, which began in
California in 1960, has spread
nationwide and now includes
eighty-seven restaurants in sixteen states. Pancake totals of
the best eaters in the Baltimore
contest will be compared wih
those of hundreds of other collegians across the country to
determine the winners. Other
Universities competing include
Southern California, UCLA,
Miami of Florida, Harvard, Radcliffe, and Yale.
Judges for the contest will be
Baltimorean civic and business
leaders as well as representatives
of both Hopkins and Gaudier.
The restaurant authorities invite
all students blessed with strong
stomach to attend also.
Shrove Tuesday, the day before
Lent, is a natural pick for the
Contest. It has been traditicnaly
set aside or the consumption of
hordes of pancakes.
Last year's grand prize winners
Were awarded all-expense paid
trips to London, England.

In the annual report of the President, printed in
the February issue of the Johns Hopkins Magazine, Dr.
Eisenhower shows himself to he a man keenly aware
of the manifold and complex objectives, methods, and
problems of Hopkins.
In his report, devoted almost exclusively to a
discussion of the Long Range Planning Committee,

industry. Since then, Jim Brown has continued to
take courses that will help him keep up with the
newest engineering techniques in communications.

engineering studies, has given Jim the ability to
develop his talents to the fullest extent. His present

1. F. Stone, noted political commentator, and editor, addressed
the assembled demonstrators. He
stressed the catastrophic effects
of any nuclear war, and gave a
detailed history of Vietnam from
World War II to the present. He
stressed our failure to live up to
the Atlantic Charter when we
did not persuade the French to
get out of Indo China as we had
led these people to believe.

agreement by its refusal to allow
free elections and by our arms
buildup. He described Ho Chi
Minh as a Nationalist leader who
was forced into the aims of the
Communists by American opposition. Stone praised the Johnson
Administration's policies in Eastern Europe and suggested that
they also be applied to the situation in the Far East. He concluded that the Vietnamese War
was not primarily an invasion
from the North but, rather, a
civil war. He finally stressed that
the North Vietnamese government was not installed as a puppet government but was elected
by an overwhelming majority of
the people.

THE BEARD OF AVON
Topic for today is that perennial favorite of English majorsil
that ever-popular crowd pleaser, that good sport and great
American—William Shakespeare (or "The Swedish Nightin.
gale" as he is better known as).
First let us examine the persistent theory that Shakespeare (or
"The Pearl of the Pacific" as he is jocularly called) is not the
real author of his plays. Advocates of this theory insist the plays
are so full of classical allusions and learned references that. they
couldn't possibly have been written by the son of an illiterate
country butcher.
To which I reply "Faugh!" Was not the great Spinoza's fat her
a humble woodcutter? Was not the immortal Isaac N \\ 11111'S
father a simple second baseman?(The elder Newton,itici(lcittal-;
ly, is one of history's truly pathetic figures. He was, by all accounts, the greatest second baseman of his time, but baseball,!
alas, had not yet been invented. It used to break young Isaac's
heart to see his father get up every morning, put on uniform,
spikes, glove, and cap, and stand alertly behind second base,
bent forward, eyes narrowed, waiting, waiting, waiting. That's
all—waiting. Isaac loyally sat in the bleachers and yelled "Good
show, Dad!" and stuff like that, but everyone else in town sniggered derisively, made coarse gestures, and pelted the Newtons
with overripe fruit—figs for the elder Newton, apples for the
younger. Thus, as we all know, the famous moment came when
Isaac Newton,struck in the head with an apple, leapt to his feet,
shouted "Europa!" and announced the third law of motion:"For
every action there is an opposite and equal reaction!'

But I digress. Back to Shakespeare (or "The Gem of the
Ocean" as he was ribaldly- appelated).
Shakespeare's most important play is, of course, Hamlet (or,
as it is frequently called, Macbeth). This play tells in living color
the story of Hamlet., Prince of Denmark, who one night sees a
ghost upon the battlements.(Possibly it is a goat he sees; I have
a first folio that is frankly not too legible.) Anyhow,Hamlet is so
upset by seeing this ghost (or goat.) that he stabs Polonius and
Brer Bodkin. He is thereupon banished to a leather factory by
the king, who hollers, "Get thee to a tannery!" Thereupon
Ophelia refuses her food until Laertes shouts, "Get thee to a
beanery!" Ophelia is so cross that she chases her little dog out of
the room,crying,"Out,damned Spot!" She is fined fifty shillings
for cussing, but Portia,in an eloquent plea, gets the sentence
muted to life imprisonment. Thereupon King Lear and Queen
Mab proclaim a festival—complete with kissing games and a
pie-eating contest. Everybody has a perfectly splendid time until
Banquo's ghost(or goat)shows up. This so unhinges Richard III
that he drowns his cousin, Butt Malmsey. This leads to a lively
discussion, during which everyone is killed. The little dog Spot
returns to utter the immortal curtain lines:
Our hero now has croaked,
And so's our prima donna.
Bid be of cheer, myfriends.
You'll always have Personna.
